coredata.dc:description: Typical antineoplastic agent doxorubicin (DOX) contamination is a major environmental concern and its efficient purification remains a daunting challenge so far. This work explored the potential of Fe/Pd-doped graphite carbon nitride (g-C3N4@Fe/Pd) for DOX removal from water, involving the removal performance, mechanism, and pathway. Structural characterization of g-C3N4@Fe/Pd showed that the metallic Pd clusters are decorated on the surface of uniformly distributed iron nanoparticles (~ 28 nm) on g-C3N4. The existence of g-C3N4 effectively relieved the agglomeration and overgrowth of iron nanoparticles, the strong coupling effect among the Fe, Pd and N demonstrates the excellent DOX removal performance (k = 0.115 min−1) with versatility under different initial concentrations (30–150 mg/L) and material dosages (0.1–0.4 g/L). Three possible degradation pathways of DOX were proposed, where catalytic saccharide moiety elimination is the primary pathway. Importantly, intermediates exhibit lower toxicity and the final degradation product is efficiently adsorbed by g-C3N4@Fe/Pd.

head.ce:title: Facile construction of Fe/Pd-doped graphite carbon nitride for effective removal of doxorubicin: Performance, mechanism and degradation pathways

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Typical antineoplastic agent doxorubicin (DOX) contamination is a major environmental concern and its efficient purification remains a daunting challenge so far. This work explored the potential of Fe/Pd-doped graphite carbon nitride (g-C3N4@Fe/Pd) for DOX removal from water, involving the removal performance, mechanism, and pathway. Structural characterization of g-C3N4@Fe/Pd showed that the metallic Pd clusters are decorated on the surface of uniformly distributed iron nanoparticles (~ 28 nm) on g-C3N4. The existence of g-C3N4 effectively relieved the agglomeration and overgrowth of iron nanoparticles, the strong coupling effect among the Fe, Pd and N demonstrates the excellent DOX removal performance (k = 0.115 min−1) with versatility under different initial concentrations (30–150 mg/L) and material dosages (0.1–0.4 g/L). Three possible degradation pathways of DOX were proposed, where catalytic saccharide moiety elimination is the primary pathway. Importantly, intermediates exhibit lower toxicity and the final degradation product is efficiently adsorbed by g-C3N4@Fe/Pd.

ce:section.ce:para: Doxorubicin hydrochloride (DOX), an anthracycline glycoside antibiotic with aromatic rings, is a typical antineoplastic agent widely employed in cancer chemotherapy [1]. However, the DOX is poorly metabolized in body’s following administration. As a result, high concentrations of DOX ranging from ng/L to μg/L were frequently detected in hospital sewage and natural aquatic systems. [2,3]. The poorly biodegradable, highly hazardous, mutagenic, teratogenic, or carcinogenic residues of DOX will cause long-term side effects on the ecosystem and humans [4,5]. Thus, DOX-contaminated media need urgent remediation to minimize its potential ecological risks.

Recently, some efforts have been devoted to coping with DOX contamination using such methods as membrane technology [6], photooxidation [7], adsorption [8], and electrochemical remediation [9]. Despite the potential of the technologies in DOX removal, the rigorous operating conditions or low efficiency limit their large-scale application. Thus, finding an additional remediation treatment to remove DOX is a critical need. The nano-sized iron material has received significant attentions over the past decade for its efficiency in organic pollutions cleanup [10,11]. The unique properties of iron nanoparticles, such as strong reductive capability (Fe2++ 2e− → Fe(s), E0 = −0.44 V), low cost, and environmental friendliness, render it to be one of the most prevalently used environmental engineered materials [12,13]. While iron nanoparticles have unique and intrinsic properties, various functionalization strategies have been adopted for exciting enhanced performance, shedding light on designing more favorable Fe-based materials. By incorporating a second noble metal (e.g., Pd, Ni, Ag, Pt, and Co) to form Fe-M (M refers to noble metal) bimetallic nanoparticles, a dramatic increase in activity can be achieved due to noble metal additive catalysis and accelerated electron transfer in the bimetallic system [14–16]. Their good degradation performance for dyes [17], pesticides [18,19], and phenolic compounds [20,21] has been reported previously. These studies enlightened us that Fe-M may also be a potential candidate for DOX remediation. However, two critical aspects need to be considered carefully before the application. Firstly, the stability of Fe-M should be improved in an appropriate manner. Secondly, the aggregation of nano-sized Fe-M particles shields their active sites to a great extent [22,23].

It is reported that introduction of a host material can solve the above problems. Host materials of high specific surface area, such as biochar [22], bentonite [24], and graphene [25] can support large amounts of Fe-M bimetallic nanoparticles and therefore, can contribute to the impressive improvements in various performance. However, bimetallic particles with averagely large and polydisperse sizes are generally obtained with existing host materials because of the relatively weak interaction between the host material and metal species. The weak interaction often leads to the uncontrollable overgrowth of Fe-M particles. To overcome this limitation, the strategy of selectively access the ligand effect has been proposed recently; that is, construction of Fe-M/host material composites by the interaction between metal species and host material that possesses several ligands. The hosts enriched in several ligands show strong interactions with metal species; covalent bonding is not involved and the only charge transfer occurs at the interface [26]. Among various hosts, N-containing carbon materials are attracting more attention. The introduction of electron-enriched N atoms leads to the localization of π states near the Fermi level around the defective site with charge redistribution between the N atom and the neighboring C atoms [27]. Driven by strong electrostatic interaction of metal species/ligands on the host, such localized N sites can act as nucleation centers for metal particles, which in turn preventing aggregation and overgrowth of nanocrystals [28,29].

Graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4), a typical two-dimensional layered material with high nitrogen content (57 at%), is of low-cost, chemically stable, and nontoxic [30,31]. The existence of massive nitrogen sites (i.e., involving -imino (-NH) and -amino (-NH2) groups) can supply strong interactions with metal elements via ligand effects [32]. Thus, g-C3N4 can be considered as an ideal host for the support and dispersion of Fe-M bimetallic particles. Moreover, g-C3N4 possesses well-ordered tri-s-triazine (C6N7) units that are easily stacked via hydrophobic effects and π-π interactions; the conjugated π region can be regarded as highly efficient sites for adsorption of aromatic pollutants [33]. Consequently, g-C3N4 is predicted to exhibit high performance in the capture of aromatic drugs (e.g., DOX in this study) or its degradation products. Therefore, the combination of g-C3N4 and Fe-M bimetallic particles and corresponding surface engineering could present multiple merits that Fe-M particles are nano-sized, well-dispersed, highly stable, and highly effective in DOX degradation, while the occurrence of g-C3N4 can ensure the complete removal of DOX and its degradation products from water. As no study was found in the field of DOX remediation using metallic Fe-based materials to our best knowledge, this work explored the possibility of DOX removal by Fe-M and Fe-M/g-C3N4. Pd was selected as the second metal to form Fe-Pd/g-C3N4 composite (denoted as g-C3N4@Fe/Pd hereafter) due to its reportedly superior catalytic activity [15,34]. The DOX remediation efficiency, the degradation pathway, and mechanism by obtained g-C3N4@Fe/Pd were elucidated in detail, which is expected to shed light on the removal of environmental pharmaceuticals by metallic Fe-based materials.

The typical preparation of g-C3N4 was as follows: 10 g urea (CH4N2O, Aladdin Industrial Co., China) was placed in an aluminum oxide crucible and calcined at 550 °C for 4 h in air. Subsequently, the as-prepared sample was treated in the 0.1 mol/L nitric acid solution (HNO3, Shanghai Chemical Co., China) under magnetic stirring (500 rpm) for 8 h. Thereafter the resulting mixture was centrifuged, washed several times with deionized water, and finally dried at 50 °C in a vacuum drying oven.

To synthesize g-C3N4@Fe/Pd, 0.18 g of PdCl2 (Aladdin Industrial Co., China) was mixed in 100 mL of anaerobic deionized water with 1.0 g of prepared g-C3N4 in a 500 mL three-necked flask. Then, 100 mL of 2.7 g of FeCl3·6H2O (Aladdin Industrial Co., China) solution (0.1 mol/L) were added dropwise through a peristaltic pump (10 mL/min) under stirring. At the same time, 100 mL of 1.5 g NaBH4 (Aladdin Industrial Co., China) solution were pumped into the flask at a flow rate of 5 mL/min. The suspension was stirred continuously in the three-necked flask for 30 min to obtain targeted g-C3N4@Fe/Pd. Finally, the sample was collected, washed using ethanol, freeze-dried, and then stored in an N2 atmosphere until needed. The g-C3N4@Fe/Pd in our study refers to the sample with the Pd/Fe mass ratio of 2.0 wt%. Here, the Pd/Fe mass ratio of material synthesis was determined based on DOX removal performance at different Pd/Fe mass ratios. The detailed discussion was provided in the Supporting Information.

The X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) was performed on a powder X-ray diffractometer (Bruker D8 Advance; Bruker AXS, German). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) images were obtained using Cs-corrected FEI Titan™ G2 60-300 instrument (FEI Ltd., Hillsboro, USA) with electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) analyses and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) for investigation of material compositions. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses of samples were conducted using ESCALAB 250Xi (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA) with a monochromatic K-Alpha source (1486.6 eV). Fourier transforms infrared (FTIR) measurements were utilized by a Vertex-70 FTIR spectrophotometer (Brucker, German). The Tafel scan experiments were carried out on a CHI660C electrochemical workstation (Chenhua Co. Ltd., China). Temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) of CO was performed using a BELCAT-B (BEL, Japan) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector.

The stock solution of DOX (500 mg/L) was prepared by dissolving 500 mg DOX in 1 L of deionized water and purging with high-purity N2 (> 99.9%) for 2 h to eliminate the influence of dissolved oxygen. The removal efficiency of four different materials, i.e., g-C3N4, g-C3N4@Fe, nano-Fe/Pd, and g-C3N4@Fe/Pd were compared. Briefly, 0.04 g of targeted materials were added into 200 mL of 100 mg/L DOX solution at pH 7.0. The flask was agitated vigorously by a mechanical stirrer (250 rpm) at 25 °C under N2 atmosphere. A 5-mL sample of the dispersion was taken at predetermined time intervals, ranging from 1 to 120 min, and then filtered by a syringe filter (0.22 µm). In addition, the spent targeted materials were collected by centrifugation and stored in anhydrous ethanol for further characterization. The effect of initial concentration was evaluated by mixing 0.04 g of g-C3N4@Fe/Pd with 200 mL of different concentrations DOX solution ranging from 30 to 150 mg/L. A 5-mL sample of the dispersion was taken at fixed time intervals (1–90 min). The effect of g-C3N4@Fe/Pd dosage on DOX removal performance was also investigated using the general approach described above, instead by varying dosages ranging from 0.1 to 0.4 g/L.

The stability of g-C3N4@Fe/Pd was also evaluated given in situ applications. Specifically, 0.04 g of samples of g-C3N4@Fe/Pd aged for 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, and 28 days in the air were prepared and the resulting products were then mixed with 200 mL of DOX solutions at the concentration of 100 mg/L in 20 min for testing their DOX removal performance. To investigate DOX removal performance in practical water treatment, DOX (0.5 mg) was dissolved in 500 mL of three different practical water samples (i.e., river water, medical wastewater, and domestic wastewater) and then exposed to a fixed dose of g-C3N4@Fe/Pd (0.01 g/L). The river water, medical wastewater, and domestic wastewater were sampled from The Huangpu River (31°32.52′ N, 121°56.56′ E), Tongji Hospital Affiliated Tongji University Branch, and Tonghui Waste Water Treatment Plant, respectively. The sample of medical and domestic wastewater was collected from the effluent stream existing from the hospital and company. All samples were filtered through 0.22 µm membrane filters to remove the suspended solids and organisms before experiment.

The DOX concentration was tested at the absorbance at 484 nm using an ultraviolet (UV)–visible (vis) spectrophotometer (TU-1901, Beijing Puxi Inc., China). The high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC, Alliance 2695, Waters, USA) with a ACQUITY UPLC@BEH C18 column (2.1 × 50 mm, 1.7 µm, Waters, USA) was used to analyze DOX and its degradation products. A mixture of 0.1% formic acid-acetonitrile (15/85, v/v) was selected as the mobile phase, with a flow rate of 1.0 mL/min and injection volume of 10 μL. The degradation products were identified by an LC-MS using an Ultrahigh-resolution hybrid quadrupole time-off light mass spectrometer (UPLC/Q-TOF-MS, Waters, USA). Total organic carbon (TOC) was determined on a Shimadzu TOC-VCPH analyzer (Shimadzu Co., Japan). The octanol-water distribution coefficients (log P) and toxicity of DOX and its degradation products were predicted using Molinspiration Chemoinformatics and GUSAR open-access online tool.

XRD analysis was performed to determine the phase composition of samples. As shown in Fig. 1a, two characteristic peaks at 13.0° and 27.6° in g-C3N4 could be indexed as (002) and (100) crystal planes of g-C3N4 (JCPDS 87-1526), which were attributed to the characteristic interlayer repeated packing of tri-s-triazine units and interplanar stacking of aromatic systems. Compared with g-C3N4, two reflections at approximately 2θ values of 39.8°and 44.9° corresponded to the (111) plane of metallic Pd and (110) plane of nanoscale zerovalent iron (nZVI) appeared in the XRD patterns of g-C3N4@Fe/Pd, which were consistent with the peaks in the nano-Fe/Pd diffractogram, implying that the Pd cluster and iron nanoparticles were successfully loaded onto the g-C3N4 surface.

The morphological and microstructural properties of materials were analyzed using TEM and STEM. The TEM image in Fig. 1b showed that the g-C3N4 has a wrinkled structure of layered silk-like sheets with smooth surfaces. By contrast, TEM image of g-C3N4@Fe/Pd (Fig. 1c) exhibits many observable nanoparticles uniformly decorating the surface of g-C3N4 sheets. The nanoparticles have spherically monodispersed morphology and core-shell structure with an average size of 28 nm (Fig. 1d), which has similar morphology to previously reported iron nanoparticles [6]. In combination with the XRD results, it could be confirmed that the well-dispersed nanoparticles on the surface of g-C3N4 are iron nanoparticles. Those iron nanoparticles have a smaller particle size compared to the nZVI synthesized by conventional NaBH4 reduction (~ 100 nm; Fig. S2), which might be attributed to the strong chemical interaction between nitrogen in the g-C3N4 and the anchored Fe species that largely inhibit iron nanoparticles overgrowth and agglomeration [34]. Further observation of Fig. 1d revealed that several smaller nanospheres from 2 to 3 nm in size (yellow arrow) are embedded in the shell of iron nanoparticles. Higher-magnification STEM image shows that these smaller nanospheres have a brighter matrix relative to that of iron nanoparticles (Fig. 1e), while STEM-EDS elemental imaging indicated a good correlation between the Pb signal and the bright region (Fig. 1f). With high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) image, the brighter nanospheres in Fig. 1e is verified to be metallic Pd, corresponding to the typical Pd(111) plane (inserted in Fig. 1g). More importantly, HRTEM image in Fig. 1g reveals that these Pd clusters are directly attached to the iron nanoparticle, which allows the formation of galvanic couples between Fe (anode) and Pd (cathode) during pollutants removal (the redox potential of 1.8 and 2.2 V for Fe and Pd, respectively).

The surface chemical state of samples was investigated using EELS characterization. The Fe L2.3 EELS edges imprint the oxidation and coordination state differences, which were usually identified by the chemical shift and the L3/L2 “white-line” intensity ratio. Here, the EELS spectra were obtained from the decorated iron nanoparticles at the outer surface and g-C3N4/iron nanoparticles interface (labeled A and B in Fig. S3). As shown in Fig. 1h, the L3/L2 intensity ratio in region A is significantly higher than that in region B (4.2 vs. 3.7), which represents greater abundance of iron oxidation state on the surface of decorated iron nanoparticles. In addition, the Fe L3-edge of the surface region of decorated iron nanoparticles showed a higher energy loss value than that of the g-C3N4/iron nanoparticles interface, indicating the lower valence of Fe species at the g-C3N4/iron nanoparticles interface. Above results indicate that g-C3N4 can improve the oxidation resistance and allow more electrons to participate in the contaminant removal process.

Additional data on the oxidation state of Fe in g-C3N4@Fe/Pd were obtained by XPS. Often enough, the Fe 2p3/2 spectra can be separated into three overlapped peaks at 712.9, 709.8, and 706.2 eV corresponding to Fe(III), Fe(II), and Fe(0), while the Fe 2p1/2 peaks of Fe(III), Fe(II), and Fe(0) appear at 728.6, 722.7, and 718.8 eV, respectively [35]. In comparison with nano-Fe/Pd, the relative area ratio of Fe(II) and Fe(0) peaks of g-C3N4@Fe/Pd are higher while that of Fe(III) peak is lower (Fig. 1i), showing a relative less content of Fe(III) species on g-C3N4@Fe/Pd than that on nano-Fe/Pd, which further indicates that g-C3N4 contributes to the suppression of oxidation of iron nanoparticles. Besides, two characteristic peaks at 333.2 and 338.4 eV assigned to Pd 3d 3/2 and Pd 3d 5/2 of metallic Pd are found in the Pd 3d spectra (Fig. 1j), implying that metallic Pd is present in the g-C3N4@Fe/Pd, which is in accordance with the XRD results. Those binding energies were lower than those of typical Pd(0) (335.0 and 340.3 eV, respectively), indicating higher electronic density of metallic Pd in g-C3N4@Fe/Pd. This phenomenon could be interpreted as the strong charge transfer from metallic Fe to Pd cluster in the Fe-Pd system [36,37].

To evaluate the electron transfer properties of g-C3N4@Fe/Pd, the corrosion potentials of g-C3N4@Fe, g-C3N4@Fe/Pd, and nano-Fe/Pd were compared by Tafel curve. The results (Fig. 1k) showed that the corrosion potentials for g-C3N4@Fe, nano-Fe/Pd, and g-C3N4@Fe/Pd were −0.64, −0.66, and −0.69 V, respectively. The lower corrosion potential of g-C3N4@Fe/Pd relative to g-C3N4@Fe was clearly observed, indicating a quicker electron transfer rate after the introduction of Pd clusters. Meanwhile, g-C3N4@Fe/Pd has a higher electron transfer rate than nano-Fe/Pd, which might be attributed to the dispersion of g-C3N4 to nano-Fe/Pd leading to more active sites being exposed. The electron transfer rates were quantified by fitting the Tafel curves. The corrosion current of g-C3N4@Fe/Pd was calculated to be 0.92 mA/cm2, which is significantly higher than that of nano-Fe/Pd (0.61 mA/cm2) and g-C3N4@Fe (0.50 mA/cm2). The g-C3N4@Fe/Pd with a high electron transfer rate is expected to show excellent degradation activity for DOX.

All characterization clearly presented the structure of the g-C3N4@Fe/Pd, where iron nanoparticles were uniformly distributed on the g-C3N4 sheet and Pd clusters were decorated on the surface of iron nanoparticles. The obtained g-C3N4@Fe/Pd had a high electron density as well as transfer rate, and all these characteristics could make it be a favorable material for DOX removal.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Comparison of DOX removal by various materials
ce:section.ce:para:
The DOX removal performance of g-C3N4, g-C3N4@Fe, nano-Fe/Pd, and g-C3N4@Fe/Pd were compared. As shown in Fig. 2a, significant differences in DOX removal efficiency for four materials were observed. Among all samples, the g-C3N4 has the lowest removal ability that about 3.1% of DOX removed within 120 min. The activity of g-C3N4@Fe in reducing DOX enhanced evidently compared to g-C3N4, reaching 67.2% of removal extent in 120 min, while the removal performance is more significantly improved after introduction of Pd clusters for g-C3N4@Fe/Pd. The enhanced removal activity pointed to the crucial role of Fe-Pd interfacial sites on DOX removal. It is well known that the deposition of Pd onto iron surface allows an electrical connection between two dissimilar metals, which gives a driving force to accelerate the electron transfer. For this, the anodic reaction (anaerobic and weakly acidic environment) can be given by

Besides, the DOX removal efficiency was inferior to that of g-C3N4@Fe/Pd compared to nano-Fe/Pd, with a DOX removal of 44.2% for nano-Fe/Pd within the first 10 min versus 75.3% for g-C3N4@Fe/Pd. It can be explained by the dispersion and immobilization of nano-Fe/Pd on the g-C3N4 surface leading to exposure more reaction sites, as verified by CO-TPD characterization. As shown in Fig. S4, the slight peaks at ~ 186 °C associated with the desorbed CO from Fe sites as well as peaks at ~ 268 and ~ 343 °C corresponding to bridge-bonded CO desorption on Pd sites are observed on the CO-TPD curve in both g-C3N4@Fe/Pd and nano-Fe/Pd [38,39]. Comparatively, the amount of desorbed CO from Pd sites for g-C3N4@Fe/Pd, 103 μmol/g, is much higher than nano-Fe/Pd (67 μmol/g), implying the more reaction sites for g-C3N4@Fe/Pd that is closely correlated to significantly enhanced DOX removal. The kinetics of DOX removal over all samples could be well described using pseudo-first-order model (Fig. 2b). As expected, the removal rate of g-C3N4@Fe/Pd (0.115 min−1) was significantly higher than that of g-C3N4 (0.001 min−1), g-C3N4@Fe (0.011 min−1), and nano-Fe/Pd (0.029 min−1), demonstrating that iron nanoparticles, Pd clusters, and g-C3N4 on g-C3N4@Fe/Pd synergistically contributed to the effective DOX removal.

ce:section.ce:section-title: DOX removal by g-C3N4@Fe/Pd under different conditions
ce:section.ce:para: The versatility of g-C3N4@Fe/Pd for DOX removal under different conditions is of general significance. The eﬀects of initial concentration on DOX removal were first evaluated by batch experiments. As depicted in Fig. 2c, the DOX removal efficiency decreases from 98.2% to 48.3% within 10 min as the initial DOX concentration increases from 30 to 150 mg/L. Meanwhile, the kinetics of DOX removal fits well with the first-order model, showing a drop in kobs value from 0.821 min−1 at an initial DOX concentration of 30 mg/L to 0.029 min−1 at 150 mg/L (Fig. S5a). The removal process of anthraquinone compounds involving noble metals was generally considered to be a heterogeneous reaction with noble metal acting as a catalyst. Given the limited reactive sites in g-C3N4@Fe/Pd under fixed loading of Pd clusters, the increasing competition among DOX molecules at higher initial DOX concentration caused a decline in removal efficiency. The effect of sample dosage on g-C3N4@Fe/Pd efficiency in removing DOX was also conducted. It’s noted that the removal efficiency improved when mixtures dosage increased from 0.1 to 0.3 g/L as more active sites participate in reactions, where 92.0% of DOX was removed using 0.3 g/L dosage while only 71.7% was achieved using 0.1 g/L dosage within 30 min (Fig. 2d). Higher dosage (0.4 g/L) did not significantly change the removal efficiency of DOX as similar kobs with that of 0.3 g/L dosage (0.137 min−1 for 0.3 g/L vs. 0.151 min−1 for 0.4 g/L) (Fig. S5b), which could be explained that the excessive sample blocked part of the active sites and thus the reactivity of g-C3N4@Fe/Pd was no longer strengthened.

To explore the DOX removal mechanism by g-C3N4@Fe/Pd, the evolution of UV–vis spectra with reaction time was first investigated. As shown in Fig. 3a, the original absorption peak of DOX centered at 484 nm decreases and a new peak (λmax = 608 nm) in the red region appeared after exposure to g-C3N4@Fe/Pd, which implies that partially DOX was degraded into other substances. The new absorption peak at a higher wavelength suggested the formation of the complex with a more extended π-delocalization length, which reduced π-π* transition energy and therefore changed the color of solution to brown in 5 min (inset of Fig. 3a) [40]. Intriguingly, the new peak increases to a maximum at 5 min and then decreases rapidly, accompanied by the solution turning colorless. Meanwhile, no other significant new characteristic wavelength emerges as the decrease of new peak area at λmax = 608 nm, which might be attributed to the effective adsorption of degradation products onto g-C3N4@Fe/Pd surface. The corresponding HPLC chromatograms further confirmed such adsorption process. It was found that both the solution after 30 min of reaction and metabolite extract of the post-reaction samples had detected the peaks of degradation product at the same retention time (9.9 and 17.6 min) (Fig. 3b). The relative low peak intensity of reacted g-C3N4@Fe/Pd extracted solution suggested that the adsorption of degradation products onto g-C3N4@Fe/Pd was a chemisorption process. As such, most degradation products were not easily released into the methanol. For this, the removal of DOX by g-C3N4@Fe/Pd could be considered as a degradation-adsorption process, in which g-C3N4@Fe/Pd could not only degrade DOX but also capture its degradation products. In addition, essentially no TOC was detected after 3 h of reaction even at high initial DOX concentration (100 mg/L; Fig. S6), which showed the superior adsorption performance of g-C3N4@Fe/Pd for degradation products. The negligible residual complexes in the aqueous solution after reaction highlighted that g-C3N4@Fe/Pd was a promising material employing degradation followed by in-situ adsorption of degradation products strategy for ultimate purification of DOX-contaminated media. On the other hand, cycling experiments showed that the g-C3N4@Fe/Pd can be recycled at least five times (Fig. S7). Only trace amounts of degradation products were detected in solution although the DOX cannot be completely degraded after 6th reuse (Fig. S8), implying the final products degraded by Fe/Pd nanoparticles are sufficient to be absorbed by the g-C3N4@Fe/Pd. In this regard, we can assume that the rate-determining factor is the electron donating ability of iron nanoparticles rather than the amount of adsorption sites for degradation products on the g-C3N4@Fe/Pd.

The various intermediates during the degradation reaction were identified with LC-MS to better understand the synchronous degradation and adsorption property of g-C3N4@Fe/Pd. Four byproducts of DOX were detected according to the obtained chromatographic profiles and MS spectra. The chromatographic retention times, molecular mass, compound name, and proposed structure were listed in Table S1. The peak occurring at the retention time (Rt) of 16.4 min in the chromatogram before reaction is referred to as DOX molecule (Fig. 3b), which presents the heaviest and major peak at mass-to-charge ratio (m/z) ratio of 544 (Fig. S9). After 5 min of degradation, the DOX peak at Rt = 16.3 min decreases and relatively strong peaks ascribed to doxorubicinolone (Rt = 13.0 min, m/z = 415, TP1), 7-deoxydoxorubicinone (Rt = 9.9 min, m/z = 399, TP2), 6,8,11-trihydroxy-8-(2-hydroxyacetyl)-1-methoxy-7,8-dihydrotetracene-5,12-dione (Rt = 9.1 min m/z = 397, TP3), and 6,11-dihydroxy-8-(2-hydroxyacetyl)-1-methoxytetracene-5,12-dione (Rt = 17.6 min, m/z = 378, TP4) are observed [41,42]. The degradation pathways of these intermediates may differ due to several factors such as the presence of different active species during the reaction and multiple active sites for DOX. As shown in Scheme 1, three different degradation mechanisms at the primary degradation route of DOX were proposed: (1) hydrolysis (TP1), (2) catalytic transfer hydrogenolysis (TP2), and (3) catalytic HOX elimination (TP3).

Compound TP1 was generated through hydrolysis by loss of amino sugar moiety (H-X) due to the cleavage of glycosidic linkage. The hydrolysis of DOX was limited (1–3%) in the mild alkaline media (pH after the reaction is ~ 7.5 in our case) and formed TP1 subsequently undergoes dehydration to yield TP3 [43]. The transformation of compound TP2 is a typical catalytic hydrogenolysis reaction termed “transfer hydrogenolysis”, in which the benzylic CO bond was cleaved and substituted for a hydride [44,45]. On the Pd clusters, the DOX molecule with aromatic ring structure have strong interaction with the surface, allowing DOX to lie nearly parallel to the substrate ( Scheme 2) [46]. Then Pd-catalyzed benzylic CO bond scission by insertion of Pd into CO bond takes place, which was generally accepted based on previous surface science studies on Pd(111) surfaces [44,47]. The newly formed OX would be hydrogenated to HOX owing to the existence of absorbed hydrogen radical (H*) on the Pd clusters surface, where * denotes the surface species/sites on the Pd clusters [48]. On the other side, the formed hydrocarbon residue (HR) was temporarily bound on the surfaces of Pd clusters, followed by hydrogenation so that TP2 was produced (Path A). The hydrogen species in the hydrogenation reaction originated from the H* on the surface of Pd clusters. Meanwhile, the β-hydride elimination on HR could also occur as the strong hydrogen stabilization for Pd clusters and that gave rise to compound TP3 transformation (Path B). After that, the intermediate product TP3 would be dehydrated to compound TP4 or further reduced to yield compound TP2.

More importantly, the chromatogram results of reaction for 30 min demonstrated that TP4 is the major final product, which implied that the hydrogenation reaction on HR (Path A) was overwhelmed by the β-hydride elimination (Path B). As the kA/kB is a constant, the θH*/θ* is considered to be an important parameter for determining the selectivity of hydrogenation and dehydrogenation reactions. The selectivity to hydrogenation toward HR over β-hydride elimination was favored with increasing H* coverage. As expected, the experiments of DOX removal with g-C3N4@Fe/Pd at varied H2 concentrations showed that a higher stoichiometric H/Pd ratio facilitated TP2 accumulation (Fig. S10). In addition, a sharp increase was observed in TP2 abundance when H/Pd molar ratio exceeded 1.5, which indicated that the predominantly hydrogenation process occurred only after the saturation of g-C3N4@Fe/Pd by hydrogen. This also explained why the g-C3N4@Fe/Pd conducting major electrons mediated β-hydride elimination on HR under N2 atmosphere. Such observation correlated well with the study of tetralin dehydrogenation on Pd catalysts showing the dehydrogenation ability dependent on the initial rate of H* evolution [49].

Note that the TP4 was the major product and then we verified its adsorption by FTIR analysis. FTIR spectra of g-C3N4@Fe/Pd, reacted g-C3N4@Fe/Pd, and DOX are shown in Fig. 4a. The adsorption bands of g-C3N4@Fe/Pd at 811, 1462, 1575, and 1643 cm−1 correspond to the stretching vibrations of the heptazine-derived rings, and the peaks at 1240 and 1320 cm−1 were attributed to secondary (2CN) and tertiary (3CN) amine fragments on g-C3N4, respectively [32,50]. After g-C3N4@Fe/Pd reacted with DOX, the FTIR spectra showed characteristic peaks related to stretching vibration of CC bonds in aromatic structures (1518 and 1560 cm−1) [51]. The bands at 1002 cm−1 were assigned to the stretching vibrations of CO and the broad peak at 1037 cm−1 was linked to COH stretching vibrations [52]. Compared with the spectra of DOX, no nitrogen-containing functional groups associated with the amino sugar group, such as δ(NH) (1523 cm−1), w(NH) (802 cm−1), and v(CN) (1285 cm−1), are observed in the reacted g-C3N4@Fe/Pd. Moreover, the new peak related to stretching vibration of carbonyl group shifted from 1720 to 1689 cm−1, which might be caused by the interaction between carbonyl group and benzene ring, indicating the presence of compound TP4 rather than DOX on the reacted g-C3N4@Fe/Pd.

To further demonstrate the processes in TP4 immobilization, the variation in the abundance of TP4 over time during the reactions between g-C3N4@Fe/Pd and nano-Fe/Pd with DOX were compared. As shown in Fig. 4b, when DOX interacted with g-C3N4@Fe/Pd, the abundance of TP4 rose rapidly at the beginning and then gradually decreased, while the abundance of TP4 increased continuously then plateaued during the interaction between DOX and nano-Fe/Pd. Results clearly suggested that g-C3N4 provided most adsorption sites for TP4 immobilization in the g-C3N4@Fe/Pd-DOX interaction. In this regard, a rising question is, why a substantial amount of TP4 could be sequestered by g-C3N4 while this was not the case for DOX (the adsorption capacity is 8.1 mg/g as indicated in Fig. 2a), given that both TP4 and DOX grouped in the hydrotetracene ring system. Since the adsorption of organic compounds is significantly correlated with its hydrophobic properties [53], one plausible explanation is that higher log P of TP4 (3.12) than DOX (0.57) leads to enhanced adsorption by hydrophobic g-C3N4. On the other hand, the π–π interactions have been widely accepted as one of the predominant driving forces for the adsorption of aromatic compounds onto g-C3N4. The effective site of the sp2 carbon of g-C3N4 has abundant free-flowing π electrons, which could be activated by conjugation with the π electrons from aromatic compounds [54]. The tetracene-derived structure for TP4 showed an extended π-delocalization length compared to DOX as more aromatic rings exist, which could also effectively enhance the adsorption performance by strengthening π-π interactions with g-C3N4 [55].

Based on the above kinetic and spectroscopic results, the following DOX removal pathway by g-C3N4@Fe/Pd was proposed. Firstly, DOX molecules diffuse onto the surface of g-C3N4@Fe/Pd and are activated by Pd NPs. Then, the multiple reaction pathways occur at the initial reaction stage, but the catalytic HOX elimination pathway forming TP3 is the main route instead of the hydrolysis and catalytic transfer hydrogenolysis pathway. During the process, the Pd species and iron nanoparticles cooperate synergistically to effect β-hydride elimination of HR. Furthermore, compound TP4 as the major final product conversed from TP3 was effectively adsorbed by g-C3N4 due to its superior affinity toward g-C3N4, which is critical to determine environmental safety.

The toxicity investigations of DOX and its degradation products are necessary to comprehensively evaluate the potential risk during DOX degradation with g-C3N4@Fe/Pd. It is well known that different factors such as hydrophobicity, electronic distribution, and molecule size affect the toxicity of molecules to organisms [41]. The calculation of the acute toxicity of DOX and all intermediates was carried out with the assistance of the GUSAR software using rats as model organisms (Table S2). Higher rat LC50 value means lower toxicity, and predicted LC50 value for DOX (27,810 mg/kg) allowed to refer it to moderately toxic one corresponding to toxicity class 3. After reacted with g-C3N4@Fe/Pd, the individual toxicity of each intermediate exhibits lower toxicity (4 and 5 categories of danger) with higher LD50 values (within 72,860–337,000 mg/kg). The variation on LC50 index indicated reduced toxicity during DOX degradation. Meanwhile, g-C3N4@Fe/Pd has favorable adsorption ability toward the major degradation product (i.e., TP4), which would further weaken the toxicity after degradation in the treated water, suggesting that the proposed degradation-adsorption technique by employing g-C3N4@Fe/Pd is a “green” and “safe” process for DOX elimination.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Long-term air-stability test and practical application of g-C3N4@Fe/Pd
ce:section.ce:para: The long-term air-stability of g-C3N4@Fe/Pd was evaluated by reacting 100 mg/L of DOX with the same amount of fresh (1 day) and aged g-C3N4@Fe/Pd (i.e., 3, 7, 14, 21, and 28 days) for 20 min. The final removal efficiencies were obtained as shown in Fig. S11. It is apparent that removal efficiency was consistently maintained at around 92.1% at the first 2 timing points, followed by relatively less deterioration over the next 4 timing points. Almost 71.1% was observed when g-C3N4@Fe/Pd was kept for 28 days, which signified that g-C3N4@Fe/Pd has comparatively high stability as only 21.0% of the initial value was reduced. This decrease in reactivity might be caused by the oxidation of iron nanoparticles when g-C3N4@Fe/Pd was exposed to the air. Besides, we noted that the decreased amount of DOX removal rate for nano-Fe/Pd was more significant than that for g-C3N4@Fe/Pd after 28-day air-exposure, implying a slower oxidation rate of g-C3N4@Fe/Pd than nano-Fe/Pd, which might be attributed to the fact that g-C3N4 carrier available for retarding oxidation of iron nanoparticles. Therefore, the g-C3N4@Fe/Pd is highly expected to keep remaining functionality in a long time.

The performance of g-C3N4@Fe/Pd in DOX removal was also investigated with river water, medical wastewater, and domestic wastewater. Results showed as much as 88.2%, 86.3%, and 90.1% of the DOX in wastewater could be removed within 1 min (Fig. S12). The lower DOX removal rate for real wastewater compared to pure spiked water samples was expected, due to the competition of DOX with other inorganic or organic substances as well as microbes for binding sites on the material [56]. Nevertheless, g-C3N4@Fe/Pd showed high DOX removal efficiency in the treatment of three types of waters and acceptable for practical application. Thus, synthetic g-C3N4@Fe/Pd was proven a high-quality material with high potential for remediation of DOX-contaminated wastewater.

A novel composite of g-C3N4@Fe/Pd was successfully fabricated in this study and used in the DOX treatment. The introduction of g-C3N4 effectively inhibits overgrowth, agglomeration, and oxidation of iron nanoparticles, which resulted in the small particle size of metallic iron (~ 28 nm) uniformly distributed on the g-C3N4 sheet. The deposition of Pd clusters on the surface of iron nanoparticles is favored since Fe-Pd galvanic couple tend to form. All these factors remarkably contribute to superior degradation kinetic towards DOX (k = 0.115 min−1). Batch experiments revealed that the versatility of g-C3N4@Fe/Pd for DOX removal under different initial concentrations (30–150 mg/L) and sample dosages (0.1–0.4 g/L). Importantly, the possible degradation pathway of DOX was proposed where the catalytic HOX elimination pathway is the primary route instead of the hydrolysis and catalytic transfer hydrogenolysis pathway. The individual toxicity of each intermediate exhibits lower toxicity than DOX and the formed main finial product TP4 could be efficiently sequestered by g-C3N4 due to the strong lipotropic activity and strengthened π-π interactions with g-C3N4. Moreover, the stability test and practical application of g-C3N4@Fe/Pd were also investigated showing g-C3N4@Fe/Pd could be a high-quality material with high potential for ultimate purification of DOX-contaminated media.
